bibl.title: Letter from Atcheson Laughlin Hench to Philip Showalter Hench, December 22, 1947

div1.p: Atch Hench describes a book by Josiah Gorgas that he has sent to his brother as a Christmas gift. He also relates family and professional news.

div1.head: Letter from Atcheson Laughlin Hench to Philip Showalter Hench, December 22, 1947
div1.opener:
UNIVERSITY OF VIRGINIA
CHARLOTTESVILLE, VIRGINIA
Home and Mailing Address:
The Farm Lane, East Jefferson St.,
Charlottesville, Virginia
Dec. 22, 1947
Dear Phil,
div1.p:
Jim has already written to the whole Rochester Hench crowd
a final note. Gifts went off days and maybe some even weeks
ago. This is a separate letter to you.

You will get two small gifts from me, and then a third one
that I sent off last week. This last item is a footnote for
your yellow fever studies. I realize that Reed & Lazear are
your two main interests and that Gorgas is a very minor
one. Well, the item I am sending is not a Reed or Lazear item;
it is a Gorgas one. But I am sure you don't have it, for
it is just off the press. Nor does it deal with Gorgas
primarily; it deals with his father. Your Gorgas is a
little boy in the book, named simply “Willie.” The book is
The Civil War section of the diary that General Josiah Gorgas,
head of the supply of all guns, arms, etc. to the Confederate
Army, wrote as a journal for his boy to read. Little Willie
lived in Richmond through the War and anybody interested
in the whole story of the Panama-Canal-Gorgas who used Reed's
discovery so effectively will be interested in anything that
tells about the family he grew up in and what kind of
boyhood he had.

This book tells something of that story. But don't
expect it to be exciting. They say that General Josiah Gorgas
was one of the most capable of the service of supply generals.
But the gentleman did not write an exciting diary. Indeed
it is pretty dull. He was terribly busy and was not
inclined to put his army problems into his diary. So
the book is nothing but notes about how the war was
going and how the prices of food crept up. When you come
to the spring of 1864 when things began to look bad, the diary
becomes fuller and more interesting. The 1864 and 1865 parts
are the best.

The point of my sending you the book is that your
General Gorgas went through all this as a boy.

Margaret arrived back from Swarthmore in her new fur
coat Saturday night and immediately afterwards we all
sped off to a wedding reception.

Tomorrow we all go out into the country to the farm
of a good friend of ours who takes the kids out into the
woods and chops down for them the Christmas tree they
choose. It is always an occasion - sort of like bringing in
the Yule log in the olden days.

Now for your desire that I send you some dope about
my honors, etc. I cannot get that stuff together till
after the meeting of the American Dialect Society (of which I am
president - To be reelected, I hear, for another year) in Detroit
next week. I am being crowded by many details in
preparation for that meeting. So let me postpone sending
you the dope. A further explanation for my need for time is the
fact that Phi Beta Kappa & the Raven Society elections are only
two of several. My work & my honors are bound up together.
Article- writing for the journal American Speech produced my appoint-
ment to the advisory editorial board of that journal. These same the
articles plus a lot of other stuff I sent Mencken produced his
most kind mention of me in his introduction to Iberian Language,
Supplement I. This kind of thing - interest in research-won
me Phi Beta Kappa. This kind of thing plus something
vaguely called “interest in the University over & above things
one is obligated to do” won me the faculty and, student's fine compliment
of election to the honor society of faculty of and students, the Ravens,

Then some other things came along. I'll have to look
them up to get exact details. But I got invited to join
the advisory editorial board of Funk & Wagnall's College Standard
Dictionary (you may remember I sent Susan a copy of this-
a big red book). Then two years ago I was elected
vice-president of the Am. Dialect Society and last year
was elected president.

Also in August I was appointed on a board of
University representatives dealing with the stimulation of
research in the Richmond district for the Rockefeller
sponsored Richmond Area University Center.

Also I'm on a committee of word-hunters, more
pompously called lexicographers, who run a column or
section of American Speech called “Among the New Words”
and who publish the cream of their findings in the
Britannica Year Book under the title “Words and meanings
of the Year, New” each spring.

If you really want the low-down on me, right
from the horse's mouth, I'll have to do some rezearch
into it, and that will have to be put off till after
I'm 56 years old - next week.
Merry Christmas to all of you.
div1.closer:
Asever Atch People continue to tell me what a fine talk you made them
when you were here. The general idea is “It wasn't on
rheumatism or cancer. It was on something really
interesting to listen to.”
